dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so we've got some really interesting news dropping today, kind of shedding light on, uh, a corner of the political world that's usually pretty shadowy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so we've got some really interesting news dropping today, kind of shedding light on, uh, a corner of the political world that's usually pretty shadowy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for sure. This is actually a pretty big deal. We're talking about the first time in the whole Citizens United era that a dark money group was actually forced to disclose their donors. Like, ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for sure. This is actually a pretty big deal. We're talking about the first time in the whole Citizens United era that a dark money group was actually forced to disclose their donors. Like, ever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is the first time in the Citizens United-era that a dark money group was forced to disclose their donors in a certain time period, said Jordan Libowitz, a spokesperson for nonprofit watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, referring to the 2010 Supreme Court case that wiped away previous restrictions on political spending.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And the group, Americans for Job Security, or AJS, they, uh, they *initially* claimed they were a "socialist collective." Which, you know, is a *bit* ironic given what we now know.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And the group, Americans for Job Security, or A J S, they, uh, they initially claimed they were a socialist collective. Which, you know, is a bit ironic given what we now know.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans for Job Security had previously claimed it was not a political organization and therefore did not have to disclose its donors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Yeah, a socialist collective that, um, somehow *didn't* have to disclose its donors. But after years of fighting, a watchdog group, CREW, pushed back, and AJS finally filed a list of backers from, get this, 1970 to 1972.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a socialist collective that, um, somehow didn't have to disclose its donors. But after years of fighting, a watchdog group, C R E W, pushed back, and A J S finally filed a list of backers from, get this, nineteen seventy to nineteen seventy two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But after years of litigation, CREW convinced the Federal Election Commission otherwise. AJS filed a list of its backers and beneficiaries from 2010 to 2012 on Thursday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, like, who ended up being on this, uh, retro list of donors?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, like, who ended up being on this, uh, retro list of donors?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the biggest individual donor appears to be Charles Schwab, the brokerage titan. He, uh, he apparently gave nearly nine million dollars over three years back in '72. And then Doris Fisher, co-founder of Gap, and her sons, they gave another nine million to *oppose* the group.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the biggest individual donor appears to be Charles Schwab, the brokerage titan. And then Doris Fisher, co-founder of Gap, and her sons, they gave another nine million to oppose the group.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The biggest individual donor to the group appears to be Charles Schwab, the brokerage titan worth an estimated $7.8 billion. Over the span of three months in 2012, he donated nearly $9 million. Gap cofounder Doris Fisheralong with her sons Robert, John and Williamgave another $9 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. That's, um, fascinating. But the article also mentions that this *new* FEC filing revealed names who, like, *hadn't* contributed, or even, uh, *denied* involvement? That's confusing.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The new FEC filing shows billionaire donors from around the country. The late Republican megadonors Richard and Helen DeVos gave $1 million to the group in October 2012. Texas oil-and-gas billionaires Richard Kinder, Dan Wilks, Farris Wilks and late Houston Texans owner Robert McNair were also among the donors that year.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Texas oil-and-gas billionaires Richard Kinder, Dan Wilks, Farris Wilks and late Houston Texans owner Robert McNair were also among the donors that year. dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's AJS saying about all this? Is this, like, a comprehensive, accurate list?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Their president, Stephen DeMaura, claims the list was pulled from "ancient bank records, religious documents, and other records," and that it "contained only duplicates."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Their president, Stephen DeMaura, claims the list was pulled from ancient bank records, religious documents, and other records, and that it contained only duplicates.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a letter to the FEC, AJS president Stephen DeMaura said the list was pulled from bank records, spreadsheets and other records, noting that it probably included some duplicates.
